Authors:
Chao-jung Wu, Shean-Shong Tzean, Jin Liang Chen, Hui Fang
Ni
Title:
Pseudoplagiostoma perseae, a new species causing brown spot
disease on avocado leaves in Taiwan
Keywords:
Pseudoplagiostoma perseae, avocado, brown spot disease,
pathogenicity test
Abstract:
Avocado is one of the most important tropical fruits in
the world. In Taiwan, a brown spot disease on the leaf was commonly
found in avocado orchards. From 2017 to 2019, sixty-three fungal
isolates were collected from the brown spots or lesions on avocado
leaves in five orchards located in Chiayi, Chunghua, and Tainan
Counties, Taiwan. Ten isolates were selected and investigated through
morphological and phylogenetic analysis to clarify the identity of the
fungus. The phylogenetic analysis based on ITS, LSU and TUB sequences
showed these fungal isolates formed a distinct clade with bootstrap
value of 100% in both Maximum likelihood and Maximum parsimony analysis,
and this clade resided within the genus Pseudoplagiostoma. Compared the
morphological traits in vivo and in vitro as well as phylogenetic
relatedness with the currently known eight Pseudoplagiostoma spp., the
fungus was recognized and described as a new species, Pseudoplagiostoma
perseae, and a key to the currently known nine Pseudoplagiostoma species
was provided. Pathogenicity test was conducted via Kochs postulate on
five avocado cultivars, namely ‘Hass’, ‘Pinkerton’, ‘Tainung No.1 Tasty
Red’, ‘Tainung No.2 Green Gold’, as well as on ‘Hung Shin Yuan’, and
leaf spots were found on the all five cultivars six weeks after
inoculation. Kochs postulate validated that P. perseae is actually the
new causal agent of brown spot disease on avocado leaves.
